abstract.p: A highly flexible nonparametric regression model for predicting a response y given covariates {x<sub>k</sub>}<sub>k=1</sub><sup>d</sup> is the projection pursuit regression (PPR) model ŷ = h(x) = <tex-math>$\beta _{0}+\sum_{j}\beta _{j}f_{j}(\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{j}^{T}\mathbf{\mathit{x}})$</tex-math>, where the f<sub>j</sub> are general smooth functions with mean 0 and norm 1, and ∑<sub>k=1</sub><sup>d</sup>α <sub>kj</sub><sup>2</sup>=1. The standard PPR algorithm of Friedman and Stuetzle (1981) estimates the smooth functions f<sub>j</sub> using the supersmoother nonparametric scatterplot smoother. Friedman's algorithm constructs a model with M<sub>max</sub> linear combinations, then prunes back to a simpler model of size M≤ M<sub>max</sub>, where M and M<sub>max</sub> are specified by the user. This article discusses an alternative algorithm in which the smooth functions are estimated using smoothing splines. The direction coefficients α <sub>j</sub>, the amount of smoothing in each direction, and the number of terms M and M<sub>max</sub> are determined to optimize a single generalized cross-validation measure.
